channel.title: The New Yorker
channel.description: Stay up to date on everything happening in The New Yorker and on newyorker.com.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2006 CondeNet Inc. All rights reserved.
channel.dc:creator: newyorker.com
channel.dc:subject: everything
channel.dc:rights: Copyright 2006 CondeNet Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Book News: Fashionista Failings, Palahniuk’s Secrets
item.description: Pain, Parties, Work explores Sylvia Plath’s month as a New York City fashionista. Speaking of which, author Stephen Fried apologizes for coining the word fashionista back in 1993.
item.dc:creator: Rega Jha

item.title: The Number: 552%
item.description: Despite popular support, yesterday the Senate voted down every gun-control measure it was considering. They’re backed by the gun industry, which has a lot to lose—business has been excellent of late.
item.dc:creator: Nick Traverse

item.title: Watch This Funny Canadian
item.description: The comedian Nathan Fielder has a Comedy Central show “Nathan For You,” in which he helps struggling small-business owners implement marketing strategies that, though seemingly very stupid, often sort of work.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Arons

item.title: Finish the Race: Obama in Boston
item.description: “Massachusetts invented America,” Governor Deval Patrick said, to applause, at Thursday morning’s interfaith service at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross, which honored the victims of the Boston Marathon bombing. It’s the kind of...
item.dc:creator: Ian Crouch

item.title: Making Money: Schooling Brooklyn Parents
item.description: As Brooklyn’s only professional school consultant, Joyce Szuflita focusses on helping parents choose the right school for their child.
item.dc:creator: Kelly Bare

item.title: Elizabeth Bishop’s National Geographic
item.description: In Elizabeth Bishop's remarkable 1971 poem ”In the Waiting Room,” she is a child of six sitting in a dentist’s waiting room in Worcester, Massachusetts.
item.dc:creator: Roger Angell

item.title: In the Land of the Coffee Nerds
item.description: At the Specialty Coffee Association of America’s twenty-fifth annual exposition, it was a piece of technology that generated the most excitement among the coffee élite. Called Modbar, it promises to radically transform the shape of the modern coffee bar for the first time in decades.
item.dc:creator: Matt Buchanan

item.title: Playlist: Boston Sounds
item.description: In the days since the Boston Marathon bombings, the nation’s attention has been focussed on the bravery and resilience of the city.
item.dc:creator: Ben Greenman

item.title: Book News: Writing in Coffee Shops, Beloved Book Covers
item.description: George Orwell’s birthplace, in India, is being turned into a memorial… to Gandhi. The birthplaces of Edith Wharton and Eugene O’Neill, meanwhile, have been turned into Starbuckses.
item.dc:creator: Andrea DenHoed

item.title: Four Reasons Why the Gun-Control Bills Failed
item.description: Wednesday’s votes were a stark reminder of how anti-democratic and dysfunctional our political architecture is.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Lizza

item.title: “Come and See the Blood in the Streets!”
item.description: Whoever planted the bombs—and ideally we’ll know a lot more about him or her or them soon—was a jackal, a stone, a viper. And it can be important to give names, as Neruda does.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Thompson

item.title: What Killed the New Electric Car
item.description: Fisker Automotive, maker of the Karma, a hundred-thousand-dollar electric-gas hybrid sports car, is in deep trouble. It’s laid off seventy-five per cent of its workforce, hasn’t produced a single car in nine months, and...
item.dc:creator: James Surowiecki

item.title: Words of Strength at a Boston Vigil
item.description: The days following the bombing at the Boston Marathon have been filled with images. Many have been grisly and terrifying: maimed bodies, blood streaked on the sidewalk, smoke filling the air. The interfaith vigil held on Tuesday night at the Arlington Street Church, which is just a few blocks down Boylston Street from the finish of the race, produced new images.
item.dc:creator: Ian Crouch

item.title: Anne Frank, Belieber?
item.description: When Justin Bieber visited the Anne Frank House last Friday, he must have noticed that the walls were tattooed with film-star photos.
item.dc:creator: Matt Weinstock

item.title: Why Boston’s Hospitals Were Ready
item.description: Explosives used in terror attacks have tended to be three times deadlier than those used in war. Nonetheless, in Boston, they survived.
item.dc:creator: Atul Gawande

item.title: Lu Lingzi’s Journey to the Marathon
item.description: On Monday afternoon, Lu joined the marathon-watchers with two other overseas Chinese friends, partaking in one of their first and more cacophonous of American traditions.
item.dc:creator: Jiayang Fan

item.title: Book News: McCartney Bio, Mourning the Phone Book
item.description: Philip Normal, a Beatles biographer who had irked Paul McCartney in the past, has received “tacit approval” from McCartney to begin work on his biography. The demise of phone books. The American Library Association...
item.dc:creator: Rega Jha

item.title: The Ricin Letters and the Fear of What Comes Next
item.description: The news on Tuesday night won’t help to calm anyone reeling from the Boston Marathon bombing: a letter sent to Senator Roger Wicker, Republican of Mississippi, has reportedly tested positive for the deadly poison ricin.
item.dc:creator: Alex Koppelman

item.title: Did Shakespeare Love the Cruellest Month?
item.description: The exactness of Shakespeare’s compressed account is wonderful. Daffodils do come before the swallows arrive, and take their chances with the often-cruel winds of March. Violets, primroses, oxlips, and fritillaries are all flowers of early spring.
item.dc:creator: Germaine Greer

item.title: Up in Smoke: Record Rereleases in the Virtual Era
item.description: Motown’s rerelease of “What Love Has…Joined Together” is virtual—there are no plans for a physical product…
item.dc:creator: Ben Greenman

item.title: Postscript: Maria Tallchief (1925-2013)
item.description: Maria Tallchief, who died last Thursday, at the age of eighty-eight, was the first grand ballerina produced by this country.
item.dc:creator: Joan Acocella

item.title: A Poem for Boston
item.description: Yesterday’s tragic events in Boston left many without limbs and some without their loved ones, so now is not the time for eloquence. But at times of tragedy, the mind goes to certain favored zones; mine goes automatically to poetry.
item.dc:creator: Dan Chiasson

item.title: Pictures from the Boston Marathon Bombing
item.description: “This was a heinous and cowardly act, and given what we now know about what took place, the F.B.I. is investigating it as an act of terrorism,” President Obama said the morning after the...
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Idea of the Week: Inequality and New York’s Subway
item.description: Income changes dramatically between boroughs and neighborhoods. One way to look at it is by tracking the shifts along the city’s subway. The interactive infographic here charts how median income swings from station to station.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Homemade Marathons
item.description: For me, the marathon was a rare, rare moment when the city seemed truly whole; when people came together—for free—to watch an event, and they cheered the back-of-the-pack plodders as enthusiastically as they did the whippets who led the way. I was so moved by it that I was choked up for most of the twenty-six miles, seeing this crazy display of community and generosity.
item.dc:creator: Susan Orlean

item.title: Two if by Sorrow: Boston and Its Losses
item.description: The bombs that went off near the finish line at this year’s Boston Marathon have so far taken the lives of three people, one of them an eight-year-old boy named Martin Richard. More than...
item.dc:creator: Jill Lepore

item.title: The Patriots’ Day Bombing
item.description: Even if you grew up in Massachusetts, which I did, Patriots’ Day is one of those holidays that take you by surprise. It’s a state holiday (also celebrated in Maine, which was once part...
item.dc:creator: Louis Menand

item.title: The Meaning of the Boston Marathon
item.description: Perhaps it was someone who spotted a terribly easy target. Or perhaps it was someone who saw a reflection of the human spirit and decided to just try to shatter it.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Thompson

item.title: Boston Marathon: Video from the Scene
item.description: Ever since the development of reliable photographic techniques, and photographer Matthew Brady’s work during the Civil War, tragedies have been linked to iconic images. They are both a record of what happened and a...
item.dc:creator: Alex Koppelman

item.title: After the Boston Marathon Explosion
item.description: At the corner of Clarendon Street and Stuart Street, near Copley Square, a woman screamed the name Lisa at intervals, panic on her face as she walked back and forth. Runners, many wrapped in...
item.dc:creator: Ian Crouch

item.title: An Explosion at the Boston Marathon
item.description: The end of a marathon is a soft target. The scene is always chaotic. Runners are delirious. And today, in Boston, though we don’t know what caused it—an accident, a deliberate act—there was horror.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Thompson

item.title: Who Said What
item.description: This is a complicated story, but here goes. Eleven years ago, for The New Yorker, I wrote a review of a biography of Primo Levi called “The Double Bond,” by Carole Angier. Levi, an...
item.dc:creator: Joan Acocella

item.title: The Crisis in a Nutshell: Quotes of the Week
item.description: A digest of the past week’s prophetic and interpretive thought.
item.dc:creator: Aswini Periyasamy

item.title: What About Denise?
item.description: A few weeks ago, students at Harvard’s Graduate School of Design started a petition for Denise Scott Brown be “retroactively acknowledged for her work deserving of a joint Pritzker Prize.”
item.dc:creator: Gareth Cook

item.title: Lucky Guys
item.description: The legend of Mike McAlary—tabloid chronicler of the crime-ridden, crack-laden New York City of the Koch-Dinkins era—has been burnished twice over: first by the man himself, who, at various times, dominated the crime pages of Newsday, the Post, and the Daily News, and again by Nora Ephron, whose stage biography Lucky Guy, starring Tom Hanks as McAlary, has just opened on Broadway.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schulman

item.title: A Note on the New York Radical Feminists
item.description: After my article about Shulamith Firestone (“Death of a Revolutionary”) ran in The New Yorker last week, I got a nice e-mail from Alix Kates Shulman, the author of “Memoirs of an Ex-Prom Queen,”...
item.dc:creator: Susan Faludi

item.title: A Great Cold War Movie
item.description: John Le Carré’s article fills in the cause of that grief’s special intensity: Martin Ritt’s sense of betrayal as the norm of political life and all of Richard Burton’s troubled relations to himself got poured into one of the most truthful and emotionally resonant movies made in the entire Cold War period.
item.dc:creator: David Denby

item.title: Shauna Lyon: Chez Sardine in the West Village review.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">The restaurateur and University of Wisconsin alum Gabriel Stulman’s clutch of downtown Manhattan restaurants, a.k.a. Little Wisco, includes the neighborhood haunts Joseph Leonard and Jeffrey’s Grocery, the trendy cocktail den Fedora, and the excellent, more rarified Perla. To this commonwealth, Stulman has recently . . .
item.dc:creator: Shauna Lyon

item.title: Sean Wilsey: Among the gondoliers of Venice.
item.description: Shortly before dawn, not so long ago, I stood in the stern of a small boat in the Venetian lagoon. I was rowing with a single oar, facing forward, heading west. Floodlights on the wharves of the mainland chemical plants, six miles away, glowed in front of me. I crossed . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Sean Wilsey

item.title: Michael Robbins: “Günter Glieben Glauchen Glöben.”
item.description:
Says here to burn the rich and take their shit. I’m paraphrasing. I’m barely grazing the surplus. Do the rich have inner lives, like little lambs and Antigone? They never give me their money.
Bill Gates, the great humanitarian, stands upon a peak in Darien. I . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Michael Robbins

item.title: Joan Acocella: New works by Mark Morris.
item.description: One thing that Mark Morris knows how to do is to create an ambiguity that feels like clarity. Often in his work, a person, after doing something that you think you understand, does something that utterly contradicts that. Or he goes on doing his thing, but someone at the side . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Joan Acocella

item.title: Hendrik Hertzberg: Margaret Thatcher’s mixed legacy.
item.description: By the dismal end of the nineteen-seventies, a series of oil shocks had sent the economies of most of the world’s developed democracies into a tailspin. Their publics were not pleased. In country after country, voters voted out the ins and voted in the outs. Ideology didn . . .
item.dc:creator: Hendrik Hertzberg

item.title: Goings on About Town: Readings and Talks
item.description: goatTitle-->“POETRY & THE CREATIVE MIND”<!--/goatTitle--> Mario Batali, Patricia Clarkson, Stew, Kathleen Turner, and many others read and discuss their favorite poems in an evening benefitting the Academy of American Poets. The New Yorker writer Calvin Trillin is the master of ceremonies. (Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Night Life
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->ROCK AND POP<!--/goatcategory--> Musicians and night-club proprietors live complicated lives; it’s advisable to check in advance to confirm engagements.
<!--goatTitle-->B. B. KING BLUES CLUB & GRILL<!--/goatTitle--> 237 W. 42nd St. (212-997-4144)—April 18 and April 20: Shuggie Otis, the son of . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Dance
item.description: goatTitle-->BALLET HISPANICO<!--/goatTitle--> Since becoming artistic director, in 2009, Eduardo Vilaro has dusted off the company he inherited. Yet, in his quest to be contemporary, he’s shown questionable taste. His latest commission, “Sortijas,” is by Cayetano Soto, a Spanish choreographer in a familiar, twitchy, post . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Classical Music
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPERA<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->METROPOLITAN OPERA<!--/goatTitle--> April 19 and April 22 at 7: Finally, after helming three convincing but conventional productions for the Met, the Scottish director David McVicar shows us what he’s made of in his staging of “Giulio Cesare,” which d&#233 . . .

item.title: David Denby: Brian Helgeland’s “42” review.
item.description: Jackie Robinson had a heart-stopping way of taking a lead off third base. He didn’t drift a few feet off the bag and wait for the pitch, as most runners do. Facing the pitcher, he hopped sideways down the line, fluttering his fingers like a hummingbird&#8217 . . .
item.dc:creator: David Denby

item.title: Books: Elif Shafak’s “Honor” review.
item.description: The sweeping title of this multigenerational novel refers to honor killing—a woman’s murder at the hands of her relatives or with their approval. Shafak follows a family’s journey from a small Kurdish village in the nineteen-forties to nineteen-nineties London, where her characters . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: David Berlinski’s “The King of Infinite Space” review.
item.description: This lively survey of the legacy of Euclid paints the geometer as “stern, logical, unrelenting, a man able to concentrate the powers of his mind on what is abstract and remote.” The axioms, theorems, proofs, and illustrations that fill Euclid’s “Elements” express the conviction . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Ben Greenman: A new album, “Small Town Talk,” from Shannon McNally and Dr. John.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">The death of Bobby Charles, in 2010, touched off a resurgence of interest in the work of the Louisiana-born singer-songwriter. The standard obituaries focussed mainly on the swamp pop that Charles pioneered in the late fifties and early sixties; he wrote “See You Later . . .
item.dc:creator: Ben Greenman
